reviews.text:
**Gateway of India - Pure Magic!**
As we stepped here, I felt my heart skip a beat!
This 85-year-old beauty left me spellbound and romantic üòç
**Rain Started - Romance Doubled!** ‚òî
- Soft raindrops on my face, warm arms around me
- Laughter and whispers under the rhythmic sound of rain
- Gateway's beauty enhanced by the rain-kissed day
What makes Gateway of India special:
- **Breathtaking Views**: Arabian Sea view from every angle
- **Romantic Strolls**: Hand-in-hand walks along the shore
- **Intricate Architecture**: History and love carved in every stone
- **Vibrant Crowd**: Happy faces and lively atmosphere around
Rating: 5/5 ‚ù§Ô∏è
Must Visit: Gateway of India - a must-visit with your loved one!

As a first-time visitor to Mumbai, seeing the Gateway of India was truly one of the highlights of my trip. The moment I arrived, I was awestruck by the grandeur of this iconic monument. The structure itself, with its impressive Indo-Saracenic architecture, stands tall and majestic, overlooking the Arabian Sea. It feels like stepping into a piece of history - you can almost imagine the days when important dignitaries arrived here during the British era.

What truly made the experience special was the breathtaking view. Facing the open sea, with the cool breeze on your face and the sound of the waves in the background, the entire scene feels both peaceful and inspiring. The area is lively yet not overwhelming - people are enjoying the view, clicking photos, or simply soaking in the atmosphere.

Right across from the Gateway stands the famous Taj Mahal Palace Hotel, which adds to the charm of the place. The view of this grand hotel alongside the Gateway is picture-perfect, especially as the sun starts to set and the lights slowly illuminate the surroundings.

Everything about my visit felt just right - the clean promenade, the vibrant energy of visitors, and the rich history all around. It's a spot where you can pause, reflect, and truly appreciate the beauty and spirit of Mumbai. I'd highly recommend it to anyone visiting the city for the first time.

üèõÔ∏è Gateway of India, Mumbai üèõÔ∏è
üìçApollo Bandar, Colaba, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

‚ú® About the Monument:
The Gateway of India is a majestic 26-meter-high triumphal arch built in the Indo-Saracenic architectural style. Completed in 1924, it was originally constructed to commemorate the visit of King George V and Queen Mary to India in 1911. Designed by Scottish architect George Wittet, it blends Gothic Revival elements with Indian and Islamic motifs, featuring intricate jali (stone latticework) and yellow basalt stone.

üìú Historical Significance:

¬∑ Symbolizes both British colonial history and India's independence.
¬∑ Served as the ceremonial entrance for British viceroys and governors.
¬∑ Witnessed the departure of the last British troops in 1948, marking the end of the British Raj.

üåç Today's Experience:

¬∑ One of Mumbai's top tourist attractions, offering stunning views of the Arabian Sea.
¬∑ A bustling hub for locals, street vendors, and photographers.
¬∑ Ferry services to Elephanta Caves, Alibaug, and other coastal destinations operate from nearby jetties.
¬∑ Illuminated at night, creating a picturesque backdrop for evening strolls.

üìå Visitor Tips:

¬∑ Best Time to Visit: Early morning or late evening to avoid crowds and enjoy pleasant weather.
¬∑ Nearby Attractions: Taj Mahal Palace Hotel, Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Museum, and Colaba Causeway.
¬∑ How to Reach: Easily accessible via taxis, buses, or local trains from Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus (CST).

üéØ Google Maps Highlights:

¬∑ Use Google Maps for real-time navigation, nearby dining recommendations, and ferry schedules.
¬∑ Explore user-generated photos and reviews to plan your visit better.
¬∑ Address descriptors and route optimization features are available for seamless travel in Mumbai.

üì∏ Photo Spot:
Don't miss capturing the grand arch with the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel in the background or the serene sea views! The monument is also a popular spot for Hanukkah celebrations and cultural events.

üîó Learn More:
For detailed historical context and virtual tours, check out the Google Arts & Culture feature on the Gateway of India.

places.generalDescription: Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus, formerly known as Victoria Terminus Station, is a historic train station in Mumbai. It was built in 1887 to replace the former Bori Bunder station due to increased rail traffic. The station's impressive architectural design combines British Victorian Gothic and Indian styles, earning it recognition as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

sources.snippet: If you appreciate architectural marvels, the Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus is a must-visit. reviews.text: Very impressive Victorian architecture on the outside, and a great experience to walk around inside and on the platforms, well worth a visit if you are nearby - definitely try a local train if you've never experienced Indian railways!

Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus (CSMT) is a stunning railway station and a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Mumbai. Its grand Victorian Gothic architecture, intricate carvings, and historical significance make it a must-see landmark. Despite being over a century old, it remains a bustling hub connecting millions daily. A perfect blend of heritage and function.

Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus, commonly known as CSMT, is not just a railway station-it's a living symbol of Mumbai's rich history and architectural grandeur. Recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, this iconic landmark beautifully blends Victorian Gothic Revival architecture with traditional Indian elements.

From the moment you step outside the station, you are greeted by an awe-inspiring fa√ßade with ornate carvings, domes, turrets, pointed arches, and a magnificent central dome. It was originally designed by British architect Frederick William Stevens and completed in 1887 to commemorate the Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria.

Inside, the station is always bustling with activity, serving millions of commuters daily. Despite the heavy footfall, the station is well-managed, with clear signage, dedicated platforms for local and long-distance trains, and essential passenger amenities. Security is also well-maintained with the presence of RPF personnel and CCTV surveillance.

What makes CSMT truly unique is that it is a functioning transport hub and a historical monument at the same time. The stained-glass windows, high vaulted ceilings, and heritage lighting inside offer a peek into the colonial past, while the fast-paced train operations represent the pulse of modern Mumbai.

The station is well connected to major parts of the city and offers good options for local transportation, food outlets, and nearby attractions like the Gateway of India, Marine Drive, and Crawford Market.

Visiting the Global Vipassana Pagoda was truly a memorable experience for me. To reach the pagoda, I first had to travel by ferry from the gorai. The short boat ride itself felt refreshing, and after that, there was a road journey that added to the excitement. The road leading to the pagoda is surrounded by beautiful natural greenery on both sides. It is a peaceful stretch where you can enjoy the sights and sounds of nature, and traveling through this scenic route gives a very special kind of joy.

On reaching the pagoda, I was immediately impressed by its grand structure and calm surroundings. I also participated in a meditation session along with other visitors. Sitting quietly in the vast meditation hall, I felt a sense of deep peace and relaxation. The atmosphere was so serene that time passed without me even realizing it. It was an experience of true mental stillness, something that is rare to find in the busy life of the city.

The overall view of the place is equally breathtaking. The golden dome, the open surroundings, and the calm environment together create a perfect destination for anyone seeking peace of mind. I would highly recommend visiting the Global Vipassana Pagoda to experience meditation, tranquility, and the beauty of nature all at once.

reviews.text: Wander Fort is a perfect weekend spot with scenic views and historic charm. A little crowded, but great for couples and photography lovers.

Bandra Fort, also known as Castella de Aguada, is one of the most beautiful historical spots in Mumbai and is a must-visit if you love a mix of history, architecture, and stunning sea views. Located in Bandra West, this fort was built by the Portuguese in the 17th century and still carries the charm of old-world architecture.

What makes Bandra Fort truly special is its breathtaking view of the Arabian Sea and the iconic Bandra-Worli Sea Link. The sunset from here is mesmerizing and perfect for photography enthusiasts. The fort is not very large, but the stone walls, ancient structure, and lush greenery around create a peaceful and scenic vibe. It's a great spot to relax, enjoy the breeze, and take in the beauty of Mumbai's coastline.

The place is well-maintained by local authorities. The walking paths are clean, and there are benches where you can sit and admire the sea. The fort is also a popular spot for couples, friends, and tourists looking for a calm evening away from the city's chaos.

Reaching the fort is easy as it is close to Bandra's main attractions. Entry is free, which is a plus. However, parking is limited, so visiting during weekdays or early evenings is advisable to avoid crowds.

Overall, Bandra Fort is a hidden gem where history meets nature. It's perfect for history lovers, photographers, and anyone who wants a peaceful break by the sea. Highly recommended!

It's the best place to visit for gorgeous sea-link views, a beautiful fort renovated with ample seating place.

reviews.text: The Elephanta Caves are a collection of cave temples predominantly dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva. We have to take boat ride from gateway of India. Which will take around 1 hour. Average Cost of boat is around 300Rs. Be aware of monkeys. There is one toy train running from jetty to the gate which is very useful if you are with kids or elderly persons. You cab not stay there in night, so have to leave the island before sunset by last boat.

This is absolutely a worthwhile experience and highly recommended for visitors. The journey involves a scenic boat ride to and from the cave site, which, although lengthy, is rewarding upon arrival. Safety measures are in place on the boats, including the provision of life jackets.

Be prepared for long queues while boarding the ferry, especially during peak hours. It is advisable to carry essentials such as a cap or umbrella, drinking water, and sunscreen, as the area can be quite sunny and hot. Proper preparation will help ensure a more comfortable and enjoyable experience.

The ferry ride costs approximately ‚Çπ250 for a round trip. Upon arrival, visitors can either walk to the ticket counter or take a toy train, which costs around ‚Çπ10. The entry fee to the caves is about ‚Çπ40. You'll also find several small outlets selling refreshments, along with shops offering souvenirs such as magnets, bags, and unique antiques.

It's advisable to allocate at least 5‚Äì6 hours to fully explore the site and enjoy the experience at a relaxed pace. Conveniently located near the Gateway of India, this makes for a culturally rich and enjoyable day trip.

The Elephanta Caves were a great experience, other than the ferry cost, the fee to enter the caves is pretty nominal.

places.generalDescription: Sanjay Gandhi National Park, formerly known as Borivali National Park, is a sprawling forested park located in Mumbai. It is one of the largest and most popular nature reserves in India. The park is home to a diverse range of flora and fauna, including tigers and leopards. Visitors can explore the ancient Kanheri Caves within the park, which are Buddhist cave temples dating back to the first century BC.

sources.snippet: Sanjay Gandhi National Park, previously known as Borivali National Park in Mumbai is one of the popular picnic spots for locals as well as visitors of the city. The park covers about 20% of Mumbai‚Äôs geographical area and invites nature lovers to experience greenery, wildlife, rocky cliffs, caves and a number of tourist attractions located inside the park. With an area of 103 square kilometres, Sanjay Gandhi National Park is one of the largest parks situated within the city limits and is also believed to be one of Asia‚Äôs most visited parks.

sources.snippet: The History of the Sanjay Gandhi National Park Its history is long and goes back to the 4th Century BC. Two ports traded with ancient civilizations like Greece and Mesopotamia were Sopoara (in ancient India) and Kalyan (in modern India). This forest was part of the 45 km land route that connected these ports. The Kanheri Caves were an important Buddhist learning center and pilgrimage site in the middle of the park.

SANJAY GANDHI NATIONAL PARK.

One of the parks of India which is surrounded by the metropolitan cities of Maharashtra.Sanjay Gandhi National Park is an 87 km2 (34 sq mi) protected area in Mumbai, Maharashtra. It was established in 1969 with its headquarters situated at Borivali.
Also having oldest caves of India approx 2400 years old kanheri caves.

This park is home to a number of endangered species of flora and fauna. The forest area of the park houses over 1,000 plant species, 251 species of migratory, land, and water birds, 5,000 species of insects, and 40 species of mammals. In addition, the park also provides shelter to 38 species of reptiles, 9 species of amphibians, 150 species of butterflies.

places.name: The Royal Opera House, Mumbai

reviews.text: A milestone destination to be in when you're in the city of Mumbai. A place that is not only meant for stage performances, but that teleports you back to a Victorian era where grandiosity and larger-than-life performances were revered and celebrated. This is the ultimate zone for art, music, history, and motion, arts enthusiast to converge for the best, cultural and fusion events in the city. I was here for the Ibtida ek Mehfil mumbai edition which brought electronica virtuosos Techpanda and Kenzani meet Hindustani classical artforms in the most brilliant Jugalbandi ever. Highly recommend the curtains here. A must visit spot.

The Royal Opera House, located in Covent Garden, London, is one of the world's most iconic and prestigious performing arts venues. Home to both The Royal Opera and The Royal Ballet, the venue offers a truly world-class experience for lovers of classical music, opera, and ballet.

The architecture is stunning-blending historical elegance with modern renovations. The auditorium is beautifully ornate, and the acoustics are exceptional, ensuring every note and movement is felt deeply. Whether you're seated in the stalls or the upper levels, the view and sound quality remain excellent.

The performances are consistently of the highest standard, featuring internationally renowned artists and creative productions. From timeless classics to innovative new works, the programming is diverse and emotionally powerful.

The staff are professional and helpful, and the overall atmosphere is elegant yet welcoming. With various dining options and a relaxing bar, your evening becomes a full cultural experience, not just a show.
,‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è
Verdict:
A must-visit for anyone passionate about the performing arts. The Royal Opera House delivers unforgettable performances in a truly majestic setting.

reviews.text:
Stepped into Kamala Nehru Park atop Malabar Hill, and it instantly felt like a childhood memory come alive-lush, serene, and whimsically charming.
‚Ä¢	Iconic ‚ÄòShoe' Feature: The giant shoe inspired by the nursery rhyme ‚ÄúThere was an Old Woman Who Lived in a Shoe‚Äù steals the spotlight. Kids can climb it, peek through its windows, and adults can't resist the selfie opportunity. Ôøº Ôøº
‚Ä¢	Themed Makeover: After renovations in 2017‚Äì18, the park got a colorful nursery-rhyme refresh-think rainbow amphitheater, echo gazebos, a compass-view gallery, and quirky thematic touches. Ôøº
‚Ä¢	Views for Days: Perched above Chowpatty Beach and Marine Drive, it's one of the best spots in Mumbai to watch the sunset and see the Queen's Necklace light up at night. Ôøº
‚Ä¢	Serene & Well-Maintained: Despite its popularity, the park stays clean and peaceful-perfect for leisurely strolls, quiet reflection, or just a refreshing break. Ôøº
‚Ä¢	Family-Friendly: Great for kids-whether it's playing in the shoe, checking out the echo zones, or running around the flowerbeds. Bonus: entry is free. Ôøº

Tip: Mornings or weekdays are the sweet spot for a relaxed visit-crowds and heat can build up as the day goes on. Ôøº Ôøº

places.name: The Table

reviews.text: Great food outlet for pasta, burger, tacos etc. The warm Focaccia with dip was awesome. The french fries with the beans burger were also crispy and delicious üòã.

There are plenty of 5-star reviews about The Table raving about its food-and it deserves each one. The food is exceptional.

However, the service was 10-star.

Some context: I am (un)fortunate to belong to a family of hoteliers, which makes dining with them anywhere an Olympic sport. They are quite critical of poor, or even mediocre, service, and it is a pain to hear long stories about how "I have spent 40 years in the hotel industry..." each time some minor thing doesn't meet their standards.

Therefore, when I say the service was so good that my very exacting family were bowled over by the attention, the service, the speed, the efficiency, and all the other adjectives one can attach to great hospitality service.

The Table restaurant manager and his crew were exception. Warm, welcoming to begin with. Considerate of our dietary restrictions. Made appropriate recommendations so that we could have an excellent experience. It was the whole bag.

Suffice to say, you'll always be guaranteed good food at a top notch restaurant. But great service like this is unique to The Table.

Been wanting to go here since a while. Nice chill place in colaba.
The food is top class, drinks are even better. And the staff is super helpful and sweet.
The crab rockfeller and the salmon tostada were my favorites.
The avocado crostino was fresh and tasty, but the focaccia de recco had a pungent cheese smell that I just couldn't handle. My friends liked it though.
We asked for a chocolate based dessert and they didn't disappoint, I forgot the name but it tasted as good as it looked.

For drinks just tell them what kind of flavours you enjoy and they'll do their best to get you something fun.

places.name: Bandra Worli Sea Link Bridge

reviews.text: Today I was able to catch my train just because of the coastal road and the bandra Worli sea link...The Bandra-Worli Sea Link, officially known as the Rajiv Gandhi Sea Link, is a stunning cable-stayed bridge in Mumbai, India. Spanning approximately 5.6 kilometers, it connects the affluent suburbs of Bandra and Worli, significantly reducing travel time across the city's bustling traffic. Opened to the public in 2010, the bridge features elegant white towers and offers breathtaking views of the Arabian Sea and Mumbai's skyline. It stands as an engineering marvel, showcasing modern design and construction techniques. The Sea Link not only enhances connectivity but has also become an iconic symbol of Mumbai's urban landscape..

Visual treat! üåÜ Worli Sea Link bridge is an absolute delight to the eyes when you pass through this iconic road in Mumbai! üöóüí´ The stunning views of the Arabian Sea üåä, the city skyline üåÉ, and the bridge's sleek design üöß make for a mesmerizing experience. Whether you're driving or catching a glimpse from a vantage point, the Worli Sea Link won't disappoint! üì∏ It's a must-visit when in Mumbai - soak in the vibes, click some pics, and enjoy the breeze üåü. At night, the bridge looks even more breathtaking with the city lights twinkling üå†. Traffic can get busy, but the views are worth it! üòä A definite spot to check out if you're in Mumbai - you'll love the experience! üëç

If you are planning to visit Mumbai or drive around the city, the Bandra-Worli Sea Link is something you should know about.

It is an 8-lane bridge built over the sea, connecting Bandra to Worli. This means you don't have to take the long and crowded route through Mahim and Dadar.

Is it worth it? Yes. It saves a lot of time, especially during peak hours. What used to take 40‚Äì60 minutes can now take just 10‚Äì15 minutes.

Who can use it? Only four-wheelers like cars and taxis. Two-wheelers, autos, and pedestrians are not allowed. It is safe, smooth, and has fewer chances of traffic jams.

How much is the toll? It's around ‚Çπ100 for a one-way trip. A return ticket or monthly pass is also available. The toll booth is fast with digital payment options too.

How is the view? Very beautiful. You drive above the sea, and during sunset or at night, it looks amazing. But you cannot stop on the bridge to click photos.

Any traffic issues? Usually not, but sometimes it slows down due to VIP movement or accidents. Early morning or late evening is the best time for a peaceful drive.

Cleanliness and road condition? Very clean, modern, and well-maintained. Road quality is excellent.

Anything to be careful about? Maintain your speed, don't stop, and follow the lane discipline. There are cameras and police on duty.

Should you go? Definitely. Even if you're a tourist, take a cab and ask to drive through it at least once. It's not just a bridge ‚Äì it's a modern symbol of Mumbai's growth.

places.name: Versova Beach

reviews.text: Need to be cleaned, else good place for spending time with your loved ones

Versova Beach is a hidden gem nestled in the bustling city of Mumbai. With its long stretch of golden sand, the beach is perfect for an early morning stroll or winding down after a hectic day. The rhythmic sound of the waves, the cool sea breeze, and the distant call of the fishermen setting out to sea create a serene atmosphere that's hard to find in a metro city.

Top Highlights of this Beach ‚Äì
‚Ä¢ Scenic views: Versova's coastline offers a beautiful sunrise view with the sea reflecting soft pastels. It's an ideal spot for photographers and nature lovers.
‚Ä¢ Cleanliness efforts: The beach has come a long way, thanks to regular clean-up drives organized by local volunteers. You'll often see community members picking up plastic and debris, making the shoreline more enjoyable.
‚Ä¢ Community vibe: There's a strong local presence here. Fishermen at work, kids flying kites, and families spending time together give the beach a warm, communal feel.

Things to Know:
‚Ä¢ Crowd levels: Weekends and evenings can get busy, especially during festive seasons. If you prefer tranquility, visiting early in the morning is best.
‚Ä¢ Facilities: Basic amenities are available public toilets and a few food stalls serving chai, snacks, and seafood. However, don't expect luxury caf√©s or upscale eateries.
‚Ä¢ Safety: The sea can be rough at times. Swim only in designated zones and stay near lifeguard-patrolled areas. The beach is generally safe during daylight hours.

My Experience:
I visited on a serene weekday morning. The cool breeze, soft sand underfoot, and the sight of fishermen mending nets made it a calming escape. I joined a local clean-up drive, which added meaning to my visit. Though facilities are simple, the real charm lies in the untouched, local ambience.

Overall, Versova Beach is a must-visit for anyone looking for a quieter, more authentic Ayurvedic sea-breeze escape in Mumbai. I'd recommend adding your own touch by participating in volunteer activities or simply enjoying a peaceful walk.

In my opinion, every beach is serene. Versova beach is no exception. 10 mins walking distance from Versova Metro Station.

Also known as the Gharapuri Caves, the Elephanta Caves are a remarkable historical site situated near Mumbai, India. Constructed between the 5th and 6th centuries AD and discovered by a Portuguese sailor in 1534, these caves were once used as a defense point, watchtower, and practice range by Portuguese.

Hidden Gems at Elephanta Caves
Among the lesser-known features of Elephanta Island are two giant cannons situated at the top of a mountain. These cannons, capable of rotating 360¬∞, were brought by the Portuguese. Below it, you'll find large underground bunkers and storage rooms once used for machinery and ammunition. The abandoned state of these structures invites deep reflection on their historical significance and past use.

The caves are dedicated to Lord Shiva and feature intricate stone carvings depicting various gods.

Accessible by ferry boats costing around ‚Çπ300 per person, the journey itself provides beautiful views of the Arabian Sea. Upon arrival, you'll be greeted by a well-maintained site filled with captivating structures and carvings that showcase the rich history and craftsmanship of the era.

The island also has small restaurants and shops, providing convenient options for food and souvenirs. Visiting the Elephanta Caves is a must for history enthusiasts and anyone looking to experience the marvels of ancient India. The impressive carvings and the island's historical significance will leave you amazed and intrigued.

Short trip from gateway of India in Mumbai, this place has amazing sculptures/carvings in caves. Definitely worth seeing the history.

However some of the security guards do look to make some side money in addition to the entrance fee, therefore you should watch out for them approaching you with offers of pictures/information about the place.

places.name: Colaba Causeway

reviews.text: Good place to street shopping an branded shop's also

Colaba Causeway is more than just a shopping street-it's an experience! Buzzing with energy, color, and the charm of old Bombay, this iconic stretch is a haven for bargain hunters, fashion lovers, and anyone who enjoys a bit of street-style adventure.

From quirky jewelry and boho bags to vintage sunglasses, embroidered clothes, and unique souvenirs, the variety is endless. The joy is not just in what you buy, but in the thrill of the bargain. Don't hesitate to haggle-it's all part of the fun!

In between shopping, you can grab a bite at iconic spots like Caf√© Mondegar or Leopold Caf√©, both rich in history and character. Whether you're sipping cold coffee, people-watching, or just soaking in the vibe, Colaba feels like a slice of Mumbai's soul.

Pro tip: Go early to avoid the rush and wear comfortable shoes-because once you start walking and exploring, you won't want to stop!

Best shopping street, about 4-5 kms of absolute bliss as you can see true Indian culture being displayed on various levels. There are shops all the way from roadside stands selling jewelry, clothing, accessories, designer bags, belts, sunglasses to branded showrooms like Adidas, Nike, Levi's, Puma, Metro. You have access to traditional handmade Indian jewelry in various styles, designs, colors. There are cafes like Mondegar, Leopold which you can visit while shopping. All items sold at extremely reasonable prices and the shopkeepers are very much open to bargaining so both of you end up leaving the day a little bit more happier. Enjoy the walk, enjoy shoppingüòä

places.generalDescription: Manori Beach, situated near Marve Beach in Mumbai, is a pristine and serene getaway surrounded by cashew nut groves and charming Portuguese architecture. It's a popular spot for families and night parties, with easy access to Essel World via ferry. The area boasts splendid Portuguese architecture and a local church where you can experience Sunday mass. Accessible from Malad and Borivali stations, the beach offers a clean environment with lush greenery on one side and the beautiful sea on the other.

sources.snippet: If you want to visit Goa but don't have the time, Manori Beach is a great alternative. This location, near Malad, features beach shacks and a laid-back atmosphere that will make you feel like you're on a small vacation. Walk hand in hand along the beach, get a quick meal, and enjoy a calm day away from city distractions.

places.name: Manori Beach

reviews.text: It's a must-visit beach. Whether you're looking for peaceful solitude, family fun, or adventure, this place has it.

It's a windy place, full of colors and boho vibes. What makes this different from other beaches is that you get to ride ferry and roam in Marve Jetty road peacefully and enjoy sunsets and sunrise here. Beautiful place indeed.

Driving to this beach is pretty easy even with a small car. If you have large SUVs like fortuner then you may find some difficulty taking it to beach.

And you can take your vehicle to the beach as there is no parking on the road.

There is a bathroom at the entrance (on the left side) but not maintained at all. Ladies side is totally useless.

Beach itself is good enough. It's both Rocky and Sandy so nice to take pictures and all. Fairly clean.

The main attraction for me were the lots of tiny crabs. Children enjoyed running behind them.

They have few horse rides at the beach. You will find gola walas, but I did not find corns.

Verdict: It's a good beach not much crowded. So you can definitely relax and enjoy your time here.

NOTE: Please note that people drink and I found broken pieces of glass bottles at the beach. Please take care of yourself and your kids.
